ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Timothy was a superb TF. The course wouldn't have been nearly as good without him.
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Timothy Terway
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Timothy Terway
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  .
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Timothy Terway
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Timothy Terway

Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Timothy Terway
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Timothy Terway
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  .

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: The assignments to the course, particularly the journals, were extremely valuable and telling. It was a great exercise that I hope to continue even after the course has ended. The presentations and the paper were also very valuable as it gave me the opportunity to actually try out the framework in a case study of my choice (that I feel familiar with). This really increased my understanding of how to use the topics taught in this class in the real world.

Q 10: Tim frequently explained things that I otherwise couldn't understand from the lectures. I think having a motivated TF is important to making sure these complex concepts are easily understandable for students with limited experience with this subject matter.Q14: This is a course of all environmentalists/activists/problem solvers. I don't think that enough people give it serious consideration because it seems focused on land/wildlife management but it is applicable to anything.
Susan is enigmatic but dedicated, and Tim does a lot of the classroom teaching. Highly recommend talking with them both outside of class.
Very insightful learning experience. Sharing thoughts and ideas with Susan and Tim was a wonderful academic experience.

The main course book was very useful. I felt the papers regarding Podocarpus National Park were very useful for seeing how the policy sciences could be applied, and we would have benefited from more similar 'applied' readings or discussions of those papers.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The best aspects of this course were the journals, the class discussions, the presentation/paper case studies, and the TF's lectures.
Small groups, open discussions.
Reflection, tolerance from instructors, and subject content and instruction

Our class had amazingly deep, thoughtful, and personal discussions every week and I attribute this to Susan and Tim's ability to create a classroom environment that was safe and encouraged students to be vulnerable. The quality of student involvement was the best I been a part of at FES.More than most other professors, Susan cares deeply about student's learning and their preparation for the future. She is the most accessible professor I've had at FES.
Class discussions and our reflections

The opportunity for self reflection. The space for open conversation and questioning the course created. The weekly discussion group with peers. The openness to student criticism and feedback. This course is unlike anything else you'll take at FES.
Discussed topics that are extremely useful but have never been discussed in other classes. Susan Clark and Tim were extremely approachable and accessible.

This course was incredibly thought-provoking. It challenged me to think critically about everything, especially myself. We so often neglect to ask the fundamental questions about ourselves and our society. This course provided a rare opportunity for exploring them in depth within the comfort of a warm and close-knit community.
Writing the journals every week was very useful to register and analyze our growth process as we moved forward in the class.
The seminar-style of the course and journal writing made us feel comfortable discussing more personal thoughts and experiences in the classroom.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I think this course really could be aided by the addition of a more hands-on group project or field trip to apply the policy science framework in a real-life setting. I also feel that a bit more feedback from Professor Clark after our presentations would have helped me know what to work on when writing my final paper on the same topic.
More applied examples.

The actual presentation of the policy sciences material could have been clearer. And I would have appreciated hearing more about cases and applications of the framework, especially Susan's own experiences with it.
It focuses narrowly on on policy process and one theory but I'd like the space to compare others more

The main book for the course isn't particularly compelling in-and-of itself, but in application, which was light on the ground in the course. More guided application of the principles in the book, either in in class-working groups, or a pre-paper homework assignment, would be most helpful.
I think more people should take this course so maybe having the first class of the semester not be so intimidating.

I sometimes felt that the policy sciences were presented as the end-all solution, as if they didn't warrant criticism or critique. I think it would be useful to discuss potential shortcomings or alternative/hybrid problem-solving frameworks.
Perhaps it would have been useful to work with a case study closely, maybe even having field trips and talking to people to understand environmental problems from a firsthand perspective.

I would have liked more 'applied' discussions of the policy sciences in class. For example, looking at quotes from an article or a transcript to try to tease out perspectives and demands. More case study discussions to further our understanding.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: I felt the breakout groups of four were very helpful - I especially noted the usefulness of creating the groups out of people from each of the four learning styles. This really enhanced our ability to teach each other, because we each had picked up different things from class. Overall this design I think really enhanced my ability to look at things from multiple perspectives and made my contributions to the course much stronger.
At first I was not enthusiastic about having to meet with a group every week but I quickly found that we had a lot to share with each other and I looked forward to the sessions.
I would like activities for our discussion section or key topics to consider to give some guidance and set us on a path to be thinking about these things prior to class.

The out-of-class discussion section allowed us to process what we were reading and learning, and support each other in our thinking and in general. The discussion section is whatever you make of it, and that flexibility is great.
Discussions were very effective. Sometimes we didnt go over the readings as much, so this could be strengthened.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Tim was the best TA I have had. If I had to come up with a weakness it may be that students were so eager to get positively reenforced by him that they may have not been as self-reflective as they could have been. I don't know how he could change this.
Tim was hands down the best TA I've ever had. He's well on his way to being a great teacher.

Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  TIm was an excellent TF. His lectures were very well thought out and visually pleasing, and he was very clear - and a very helpful translator of Professor Clark, her guest lecturers, and my classmates comments. I really enjoyed his contributions to both the lectures and the discussions, and he was extremely helpful and patient outside of class as well. Overall his presence greatly enhanced what I got out of this course!!
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Tim was enthusiastic and clear, and a great discussion leader.
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Fantastic TA.

Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Tim is hands-down the best TA I've had at FES. He was responsible for a portion of each week's lecture and was always well prepared. His lectures were relevant, well-researched and well-executed -- and I dare say, better than some professors in other parts of the school. Tim was also very approachable and available for discussion outside of class.
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Tim was great. I wish I could think of some constructive criticism but he did a really good job lecturing and offering key insights

Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Tim is a great teacher - enthusiastic, hard working, and thorough. Sometimes he got a little carried away in his excitement over the concepts he was teaching or had been personally mulling over, sometimes he made some pretty biggeneralizations about how people think, sometimes his lectures felt a little bit like pop-psychology, but these were all mild and minor weaknesses, vastly overshadowed by his aptitude and ability to get us to think.
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Tim was an excellent TA. Highly motivated and knowledgeable, and also showed concern for each student and their particular interests or concerns.
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Great leadership of discussions, clear and engaging.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This course is very relevant to my future goals of mitigating conflict and working in professions where solving problems will be a daily requirement. The policy science framework is a great way to look at problem solving and I will definitely be using things I learned in this class in my future career.
A different and useful take on approaching interdisciplinary environmental challenges. It helped me reexamine projects i'd worked on in the past with a clearer focus on the people involved.
This course has provided me a framework from which to work to solve complex problems.

This course is about talking and listening to people who think differently than you do, about solving problems in a rational and systematic way, and about figuring out why you are at YF&ES and what you came here to do. Great.
it should be a required course.

As a natural resources manager and build upon my experience, I deal with problems that hinder sustainable management of natural resources. The framework learned from this class has equipped me with tools to analyze and solve problems. The problem orientation strategy can be applied in any policy problems, especially the ones about managing natural resources that I have to deal with in my professional life.
Very useful course for any environmental manager because it teaches a framework for problem solving that can be applied by everyone in any situation.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I took this course because I was interested in learning a new framework for problem solving for my future career. I also had heard great things about Susan and wanted to take a course with her.
I wanted to learn to approach problems differently and wanted to take a policy course.
I was interested in getting personal, hoping for a somewhat uncomfortable space to push my thinking and assumptions, and interested in learning from Susan Clark.
I was interested in learning from Susan Clark. The first class sparked my interest more than any other class.
It seemed relevant and I wanted to take a course with Susan Clark.

I devoted my time to do research and understanding ecological processes. I was looking to develop skills required to translate the outputs from my research to policy instruments with a comprehensive understanding of the needs of people and the environment.
I was interested in taking a class with Susan, since she is involved with conservation, which corresponds to my career orientation.
I thought (think) it will be extremely useful for my future career path.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes, I feel that I got a good basic grasp on the Policy Science Framework. A more hands-on field trip or case would have added to it, but the timing of one semester really limited the options for that.
Yes!
Absolutely
Far exceeded my expectations. I had no idea that the policy sciences could be such a useful tool.
Exceed them, however, it will be an ongoing process to retain and hone these skills.
It was less uncomfortable that I had expected, but I gained a lot from it.
exceeded

I didn't really know what to expect from the course. The title "Foundations of Natural Resource Policy and Management" was somewhat misleading. Perhaps it should be called simply "The Policy Sciences Framework," or something along those lines. I though the course might delve into the more technical aspects of institutions and policies. It didn't meet these expectations, but rather went beyond them to address more fundamental and critical concepts.
I have learned one framework and I will need more
Yes
YES.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: NA
A good place to clarify concepts talked about in class, and small and flexible enough for comfortable discussions.

The group discussion sessions were useful. I wonder if occasionally the TA had dropped by we might have gotten even more out of the discussions, but this was not part of the course design and would have been a lot of effort on the TA's part.
Being able to meet as a group but work on projects separately was great. Being able to test out ideas and, eventually, my presentation with a willing and thoughtful audience was very helpful.

I loved our group discussions but i think it would have been very effective if we had group assignments. This would have make us use the the policy sciences more realistically because we had to work with others to accomplish something.

It was useful to discuss class concepts in a smaller group, but there wasn't always a lot to talk about. I think it'd be better to have work group discussions sooner after class when ideas from the larger discussion are still fresh in student's minds.
The work group was helpful because we had in our group people with different perspectives and learning capacity--we learned a lot from each other.
It was great to share thoughts with others and to practice the final presentation in front of an audience.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: My advice is to come in with an open mind. This course is unlike any other course taught at Yale both in what it teaches and the way it teaches it. My classmates from this course and I all left feeling like we got to know each other both professionally and personally - and this really enhanced our ability to learn these topics. My advice is also to ask a lot of questions - Susan loves it when people ask questions and I feel that you can really learn a lot more by asking.
This course should be a real foundational course for all FES students. It was a fantastic learning experience.

Take it...with a grain of salt. Be ready to learn more about yourself in class and to learn the policy sciences partially on your own. That said, the policy sciences framework is possibly the most useful thing I have learned at Yale.
Be open to change. Although this course is loosely structured, there are key lessons to be learned that are only available to you if you're open to it.
Be prepared to be confused, frustrated, to not see the point, and to journal like a high schooler. It's totally worth it.
Don't be afraid of taking the class. With Susan and Tim's help you will get it.

If you're looking for a technical course on the policy-making process and institutions, this is not it. It is, however, an extremely unique course. I've never taken one like it, and I doubt there are others like it available at Yale or other places for that matter. It's well worth anyone's while.
I think this class is a good start for students interested in natural resources policy and management.
To participate during class and make the most out of every class session and discussion.
Do the readings, and meet with the professor and TA outside of class if you are feeling lost or just want more discussions - they are very eager to help.
